speaker: Leslie D. McKesson
words: We'll have two --

speaker: Christoble Johnson
words: to look at it

speaker: Leslie
words: Just to summarize this, as I mentioned to you, this came up as a result of doing an article for Burke County Notebook for the Morganton News Herald. The article was about the West Concord Mothers. I think, was it you, Andrea, that told me about Chris or Gary?

speaker: Christoble
words: Jeanie.

speaker: Leslie
words: Jeanie told me? Y'all's mother was Miss Lucille, right? [crosstalk] That's how we got connected, and what I would like to do is just hear your stories, your thoughts, and reflections about that time. What I'm planning to do with it is just to transcribe it, which means just have somebody type up our conversation. Save it for research, for future research, like Chris talked about, writing a book about it. Somebody could very well use this research to write a book about it. There's already a little bit of information that's been collected by the History Museum downstairs. I think there are five or 10-minute interviews, so they don't go into any detail.

speaker: Christoble
words: Yes. That's the information that they did the Mothers with it.

speaker: Leslie
words: Just to add to that and to create a storehouse for these stories. Because what I learned from listening to Andrea, I was in desegregation, but I was on the tail' end of it. I think the little kids got an easier time with it. Some of the stories that I hear are stories that need to be preserved I think so people understood that there was a battle going on with young kids. It was hard for young people. [crosstalk]

speaker: Christoble
words: It was. To me, it's painful. Very, by the way you were treated. UnGodly. Being a child that young, you would never think another human being would stoop to treat you so bad just because you want to go to school and you were another color.

speaker: Leslie
words: Before you start, let me get you to spell your name for me and tell me a little bit about what age you were at this time?

speaker: Christoble
words: Okay. My name is spelled, C-H-R-I-S-T-O-B-L-E Johnson. I was in the seventh grade. I left Mountainview Elementary School, went to the seventh grade, at Morganton Junior High. First of all, there was just maybe five or six of us, and they split us up. You don't have no power if you are separated. They split us up one to a class. You had nobody to identify with. You had nobody to sit in groups with, you had nobody to talk to in class with. You go on a field trip, you were isolated, you sat in the back of the bus all by yourself. They made sure that you got back there because they said, "Get back there." Ooh, God it's awful. I used to wait with the greatest happiness to get out of school and run up to Morganton High where my sister and brother was, for their protection to go home. That was the highlight of my day. The dread of my morning was walking with my brother to school and knowing I was going to leave him, and all my protection was gone.

speaker: Leslie
words: Was that Richard?

speaker: Christoble
words: Yeah. You got to school, You was called a nigger. In class. When they talk about slavery, they'd say, the nigga. We say, we not niggas, we negroes, and they'd look at you like, "That's what you say." They didn't try to talk about it, correct it, they'd just go right on. You didn't have no voice. You didn't have nothing. That was all. It was even worse walking to school. If I went alone, my brother had to go somewhere or my sister, I had to go alone. To walk from Bouchelle to there, I was just as scorned by the blacks.

speaker: Leslie
words: Why was that?

speaker: Christoble
words: Because they said my mother thought we were too good to go to school with them. Mountain View was just right below my house. Instead, I had to walk with them. Mountain View was just right below my house. Instead, I had to walk across town. They said, why would Miss Lucille send y'all across town when school's right below your house? You had to be bullied to get past the black section, to get up to the white section. You could be cruelly bullied and treated cruel. There was no place for me.

speaker: Leslie
words: Then how long was it from when y'all went early to the white schools?

speaker: Christoble
words: The next year.

speaker: Leslie
words: It was the next year? [crosstalk]

speaker: Richard Johnson
words: Yes. It was total integration.

speaker: Christoble
words: That's why it was so hard on us because they said, "Why can't you wait?" Everybody said, "Why do you think y'all so good, y'all can't wait." Then if we were out of school and Morganton Junior didn't have school, we had a free day, and you sitting excited about seeing the black kids coming from school. They didn't want to be bothered. They'd call you names too. They talk pure junk too. "You too good, they'd snub you."

speaker: Leslie
words: Did y'all-- [crosstalk] Go ahead, Andrea.

speaker: Andrea Chambers Lytle
words: I feel your pain because--

speaker: Christoble
words: It was painful.

speaker: Andrea
words: It was painful because like I said, a lot of people wasn't aware that Central was a school for the white folks, and that's where I got sent.

speaker: Christoble
words: I didn't know about that school you went to.

speaker: Andrea
words: Central.

speaker: Christoble
words: Central? I didn't know about Central.

speaker: Andrea
words: Robert Forney, myself, Beverly, and Marilyn was the only full blacks in that school.

speaker: Leslie
words: Tell me what grade you were in

speaker: Andrea
words: That's when I had left Mountain View and then they told me I had to go to Central. I had finished Mountain View at fifth grade, and I should have been going to sixth grade at Central, but that's when they put me in a special ed along with Robert Forney.

speaker: Christoble
words: They put him in special ed too?

speaker: Andrea
words: We were in a class taking care of the developmentally handicapped children from the folks that lived on Riverside Drive for two-- Well, it was actually two years that I felt that they stole from my life.

speaker: Christoble
words: Yes. You feel like they--

speaker: Andrea
words: A psychiatrist came in and would give us these little ink blocks test.

speaker: Christoble
words: They gave them to us too, them ink blot tests.

speaker: Andrea
words: Each time I passed the test and she said, "Mm, something's wrong." Then she'd come back the end of the year, I think I had it three times, it was on that third time she admitted that they made a mistake. I'm saying, "You made a who?"

speaker: Christoble
words: You done spent that time in there.

speaker: Richard
words: Where was the Central school at? Right here in Morganton?

speaker: Andrea
words: Where the courthouse sits. They got a picture of it. Of your article, the picture is there.

speaker: Richard
words: I didn't know about that.

speaker: Christoble
words: I never saw it till I saw the picture. I didn't either. Jeannie was telling me and then I. ..

speaker: Andrea
words: It was sitting right there where the Courthouse sits in Morganton. Then when she came back and said, "Well, we made a mistake." I said, "Well, what you going to do about it?" That's when she said, "Well, we have to talk to the principal and get with your parents and discuss it." What they ended up doing-- I said, "Well, why can't you just put me in the grade that I should be in?" She said, "We can't do that." I said, "You can't do that?" I said, "Y'all made the mistake, not me." Then she said, "Well, we'll see what the principal has to say." What they ended up doing was putting me back into fifth grade because they said that the school year was halfway over and that's where you need to go.

speaker: Christoble
words: That's how you ended up a back grade?

speaker: Andrea
words: [crosstalk] Yes. With Gary Dean. With Debra O'Neil and all them. Because I would've been ahead of you, but I got put back then.

speaker: Christoble
words: I always wondered how you got with them. She would've been ahead of me. They got people put back two grades.

speaker: Richard
words: That was a wasted two years of your life, though.

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes. Two years of my life stolen. That's the way I feel.

speaker: Christoble
words: It was stolen.

speaker: Andrea
words: It was stolen from me, and the only thing they could say was, we're sorry.

speaker: Christoble
words: Well, they didn't tell us they were sorry, they just looked at us with a snarly face. Well, you come into class, they just snarl--

speaker: Andrea
words: When I say they sorry, it was the principal and the-

speaker: Christoble
words: The school?

speaker: Andrea
words: - psychiatrist and those people were saying they're sorry, but to me, that's not-- I just couldn't accept it. It hurt. It hurt for a long time.

speaker: Christoble
words: That stuff, it does hurt. That to me, they did-- We did not make any progress. We regressed two years. Because even after integration came, we still had to go back the next year before we even got looked at as a person.

speaker: Andrea
words: That is so true. Then when I did go back for that half of a year, and then the next year I did go back to Forest Hill with my siblings to the sixth grade. Then when I went on into the junior high school, that's where like you, I had problems too.

speaker: Christoble
words: My Morganton Junior High years, that seventh, eighth-grade year is so-God, it was so damaging to me. It killed me inside because you had to be just treated so bad and suffer in silence.

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes, and the teachers wouldn't come to your rescue. They would let them kids call you every name under the sun.

speaker: Christoble
words: But the right thing. They'd leave you in the room with them by yourself.

speaker: Andrea
words: You'd go and she'd tell another student, "Well, go help her with this," with a math problem.

speaker: Christoble
words: They wouldn't help you.

speaker: Andrea
words: The student would come and call you a nigga.

speaker: Christoble
words: [laughs] They wouldn't help you.

speaker: Andrea
words: That anger got into me, and I said, "Well, guess what, I'll see you after school."

speaker: Christoble
words: That's what it ends up, you fought.

speaker: Andrea
words: As soon as I got away from Morganton Junior High school, got up by Morganton High School, because like you said, your brothers and other friends-

speaker: Christoble
words: Those were your siblings.

speaker: Andrea
words: - that's where you'd go for protection. Then once I got up there, I was walking behind her and I tapped her on the shoulder and I said, "Remember what you called me?" [chuckles] She looked at me and she said, "Nigga?" That's when Ipow

speaker: Richard
words: The fight was on?

speaker: Andrea
words: It was on, but she didn't fight me back.

speaker: Christoble
words: No, they wouldn't fight back.

speaker: Andrea
words: They ran back to the school and told the principal, and the principal contacted my parents and my mother said, that's when you going to-- If you don't stop this, you're going to the reformatory school," and I said, "That's what they say. Right?" [laughs] They say.

speaker: Christoble
words: That's what my mother used to tell us, "You just have to go through." They was trying to practice Martin Luther King's non-violence.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh, yes, yes.

speaker: Christobel
words: They just "Don't be out there fighting-acting, that's what they want you to do so they can kick you out of school."

speaker: Andrea
words: We heard that a lot too.

speaker: Christoble
words: You just don't know that back then, if my mother hadn't instilled in me about carrying a weapon, I'd carry a gun to school. I really would've. If back then, and there was guns in the house. I knew if I carried a gun, Lucille would kill me. She'd kill me dead. There is times I could have carried a gun in school, in my book bag, and killed them. Every one of them. To shut them down, and wouldn't have felt a bill of pain.

speaker: Andrea
words: How did it occur-Probably once y'all got to the ninth grade at Olive Hill

speaker: Leslie
words: Tell me about what year it is, if you can.

speaker: Christobel
words: Okay. '64, '65, '65-- '66, '67, things began to change. We got to West Concord. Well when we got to West Concord was only ninth graders. Segregation was on the swing. There was a lot of Black students, there was a lot of white students, and the Black students decided we going to beat the hell out of them if they look at us wrong. We done took enough. We'd go to school, you'd be walking in a crowd, they'd take scissors and cut your sweaters and clothes and you'd turn around and it's like, "Stop hanging off of you." So, we decided we were going to get them back. We went to they lockers and took they stuff out.

speaker: Andrea
words: Ripped it up.

speaker: Christoble
words: One good turn deserves another. Well, that didn't go over too good, we got in trouble. Because they would always punish us for doing stuff.

speaker: Leslie
words: Did the white kids get in trouble?

speaker: Christoble
words: No, they never got in trouble. A lot of them, they parents, they carried clout. They could do whatever they wanted to [crosstalk] us and we didn't get it. They didn't do nothing. Then we got the ones from Roper Street and Bouchelle Street that was gangster-like. [laughter]

speaker: Christoble
words: And it was on and popping. We had our gang, "Y'all are white, but we over here. It might be a little group but we all-- We got you." It kindly panned out-- It remediated itself, but the worst thing was we lost so many students. They quit school.

speaker: Richard
words: Yeah.

speaker: Leslie
words: Quit school?

speaker: Andrea
words: Dropped out.

speaker: Christoble
words: It was very detrimental to education. It didn't improve education. A lot of black students that would've done things with themselves, and we could've gone farther. I might've gone farther with my life, but school became a dread.

speaker: Richard
words: The teachers wouldn't assist you. If you were having difficulty learning something,

speaker: Andrea
words: They wouldn't.

speaker: Christoble
words: We were already behind.

speaker: Richard
words: They would help the White students in need of assistance.

speaker: Andrea
words: But they wouldn't help us.

speaker: Richard
words: They'd make excuses for you, "Oh, I can't do it today, maybe tomorrow you come by."

speaker: Christoble
words: They'd keep piling the work on and on.

speaker: Richard
words: I almost got discouraged and quit going. I was one of the first of five of us to go to Morganton High, integrated Morganton High. Myself, Charles Forney, Eugene Thomas, my sister Lorraine, just the first five of us.

speaker: Christoble
words: And Diane Tate, did Diane go?

speaker: Richard
words: Patricia Thomas.

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes, Patricia.

speaker: Richard
words: I hear a lot about this person went and that person went, but there was only five of us at first. [clears throat] Our mothers got together, and they decided that we needed a quality education.

speaker: Christoble
words: They didn't ask me.

speaker: Richard
words: They had more advanced curriculum books and stuff than we had. Whenever they finished with the books or whatever, it was passed down to us, but it'd be out of edition like five years or something. They thought that they sent us to a school that we could get a quality education and that was the whole concept, but once we got there, we found out that they didn't want us there.

speaker: Christoble
words: They didn't like it either.

speaker: Richard
words: It's really hard to try to concentrate and learn whenever you're in a hostile environment. "Leave your notes on your desk. Nigga, go back to Africa."

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh my Gosh.

speaker: Richard
words: Take it out their nose and wipe it all over your notes. It was rough going to school every day.

speaker: Christoble
words: People don't know. They don't know.

speaker: Richard
words: You would get threats that, "We'll catch you walking in the hall or something." It was hard to go to school and take a test if you had all that outside stuff you had to worry about. And the ones of us that survived and made it though.

speaker: Christoble
words: They did. Got by the grace of God.

speaker: Richard
words: It was worth it because we endured a lot. We endured a lot.

speaker: Christoble
words: Even during the cafeteria time, if you noticed, all the blacks was on the last lunch run. [crosstalk] Food always ran out.

speaker: Leslie
words: You were always scheduled at the end of the last shift.

speaker: Christoble
words: The food, the good food was gone. We always got-

speaker: Andrea
words: Leftovers.

speaker: Christoble
words: We'd go down there-- That's why a lot of us would skip class and go to the cafeteria. They would give yau a study hall so that you wasn't in the main flow, then we'd have study hall, and then we'd go to lunch. Not when the blacks was there. The food, if they had French fries, we got tater tots maybe and they wasn't done and cold. The food was not of good quality either. They always shifted us to be at the end.

speaker: Leslie
words: What were your classrooms like? Was there more than one black person in the class or were you kind of sifted--

speaker: Andrea
words: [crosstalk] Two at the most.

speaker: Christoble
words: It might have had two at the most.

speaker: Richard
words: At the high school, I was the only one.

speaker: Christoble
words: Yes, wouldn't have been ...

speaker: Richard
words: In every class I had, I was the only one.

speaker: Christoble
words: It wasn't no better at the high school.

speaker: Richard
words: It was difficult to.

speaker: Andrea
words: That was after everybody came over.

speaker: Christoble
words: They still managed to keep us split and no power, not to rise up.

speaker: Richard
words: Like you were talking about the lunch, you'd get your lunch and you sit at the table at a seat and three or four people get up and move to another table.

speaker: Christoble
words: Yes, that's right.

speaker: Richard
words: It was difficult.

speaker: Christoble
words: You had to eat alone, play alone. Let me tell you, at West Concord, we had dance. The teacher paired us. They called out your name, there's your partner, go stand with your partner. I was wondering who the world am I going to dance with. Because those little boys say, "I'm not dancing with no nigga." They said that right away. I know I wasn't going to dance with no boy, and they didn't have no black boy in my class. I sit there wondering what's going to happen today. They gave me the Kay-- Her name was Kay Lathop. She had a gland disorder. She was-

speaker: Andrea
words: Huge.

speaker: Christoble
words: - huge. You remember Kay? She was very huge. They didn't like her either. They put us together. She didn't like me, because she didn't like "niggas," but you know what? She began to kind of had to put up with me because she was my dance partner and we had to get a grade together. I'd tell her, "Come on, let's go get this grade," and she'd dance. She never spoke to me, she never looked me in my eye, but we danced.

speaker: Richard
words: If one did take it upon himself to try to be friends with you or whatever, and you're walking down the hall, "Nigger lovers." [laughter]

speaker: Christoble
words: You had to hear "nigger lover." [laughter]

speaker: Leslie
words: What happened to the black teachers when desegregation happened?

speaker: Christoble
words: They were just disqualified because we didn't have any.

speaker: Andrea
words: We didn't have any.

speaker: Christoble
words: We didn't have any.

speaker: Richard
words: Well, McIntosh ... with the high school.

speaker: Andrea
words: McIntosh was the only one that I could associate in the ...

speaker: Christoble
words: Identify with

speaker: Andrea
words: - middle school.

speaker: Andrea
words: Even in the ninth grade, I don't even recall the black teacher at Olive Hill.

speaker: Christoble
words: We didn't have one.

speaker: Andrea
words: Not one.

speaker: Christoble
words: McIntosh was only [crosstalk]--

speaker: Richard
words: [unintelligible 00
tags: 10] He was the only one at Morganton High. He had to be cautious because he couldn't simply give a black student his undivided attention for too long because it was--

speaker: Christoble
words: They used him to keep peace with us.

speaker: Richard
words: Yes, that's it.

speaker: Christoble
words: He was a token peacemaker because if we got out of order, they'd call him. If they had a student that wasn't acting right, being layed off school, they'd call him, and he'd get in touch with the parent. He was the liason, what you call it, because they didn't take no time with us.

speaker: Richard
words: Like my sister was talking about, we had dance too. We had ballroom dancing every Friday. I'd get the basketball and just go to-- Because we had it in the gym. I'd just go to the end of the gym is your basketball cause wouldn't nobody dance with me.

speaker: Leslie
words: By yourself.

speaker: Andrea
words: That's what it was with us.

speaker: Richard
words: I guess we had like maybe a month and a half left in school and this girl came up too, her name was Susan Fitts. Her daddy used to own the News Herald. She came up and she said, "I think it's been horrible the way we were treated y'all here." We only had maybe a month and she said, "If you don't mind, I'll dance with you ." Hell, I wanted to shoot basketball. [laugher]

speaker: Richard
words: Anyway, after that, I didn't have a problem on Friday getting somebody to dance. Because once somebody stepped up and danced with me there, on a Friday somebody else would volunteer. There was only two or three Fridays and school was over anyway. The whole year I had to shoot basketball.

speaker: Christoble
words: I had a guy like that in my class, his name was Bobby Phillips. You remember Bobby?

speaker: Andrea
words: I remember Bobby Phillips.

speaker: Christoble
words: He burned in a fire but one day we was in class and the teacher left out and this white girl had bullied me and I was there just looking at her. She was just calling out her niggas and stuff, and the rest of them, "Yes, yes," like that. Bobby said, "Why y'all treat them like that? If I had my way, I'd kiss her." [laughs] It made me feel good that he would say that. He said that trying to make them leave me alone. After that, he'd look at me and try to be my friend, but they wouldn't let him be my friend.

speaker: Andrea
words: I recall one teacher at Olive Hill when I was there. She was a PE teacher, her name was Miss Brendel.

speaker: Christoble
words: I remember her.

speaker: Andrea
words: One day she came up to me and she said, "Don't let them get you down." She said, "Keep smiling." She said, "Because you're going places in your life." I took that with me the whole time when I was going through this--

speaker: Leslie
words: All that trauma.

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes.

speaker: Christoble
words: She was young.

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes, she was a young teacher.

speaker: Christoble
words: Because she came to Morganton High and taught English to me. I was I her home room. She was very good. They dogged her, she got pregnant out of wedlock, and they dogged her--

speaker: Andrea
words: Oh, yes. You didn't do that back then.

speaker: Christoble
words: Back then they made her leave.

speaker: Leslie
words: We had two teachers in our high school [crosstalk] that would take extra time with me. Both of them were females and they would take extra time. One teacher, I'd sit right in front of my desk, and they'd leave notes and everything and she never, Oh, I don't know who loves that note, Richard. I'd say, "How in the hell can you sit there and not see who'd take something to wipe on there?" Who cannot see him do that?

speaker: Christoble
words: She didn't want to see. They didn't want to see stuff like that.

speaker: Richard
words: I guess they closed their eyes or some they looked the other way.

speaker: Christoble
words: It's almost like if they were caught trying to defend us, they will get in trouble. They'd never seen nothing. They never heard nothing. They didn't know nothing.

speaker: Andrea
words: Did you ever get paddled in school? It seems like it was always the blacks that got paddled in school.

speaker: Christoble
words: Especially in Morganton Junior High, Mr. Patton, I hated him.

speaker: Andrea
words: Thank you. (laughs]

speaker: Leslie
words: Now did the teachers do it or did they send for somebody?

speaker: Christoble
words: Send you to Patton. He had a long paddle, brown and it was thick.

speaker: Andrea
words: You had to bend over. Touch your toes.

speaker: Christoble
words: You had to bend over and he'd hit you with that paddle. He'd hit you with that paddle. Because I got hit with it a couple of times for talking back to a student and they said I was wanting to fight. I was wanting to fight but I ain't hit nobody.

speaker: Leslie
words: Was it a white student you were telling that to?

speaker: Andrea
words: They whipped us more than they did the white children. They really did.

speaker: Christoble
words: They abused us.

speaker: Richard
words: I didn't get threatened too much by the guys.

speaker: Christoble
words: I guess not. [laughs)

speaker: Richard
words: I could defend myself pretty good. I didn't have much problems with that. It was just leaving notes and threatening you. Like she said, if you hung your coat up in the closet, they'd go in and, pockets full of water, anything --

speaker: Christoble
words: One day was the coldest day, it was snowing and sleeting outside. I went to get my coat and it wasn't in my locker and Daisy Robison say, "Christoble, I think that's your coat in the bathroom in that last stall. Go look." I went in and looked. Somebody put it in there and pooped on it.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh my Lord.

speaker: Christoble
words: The coldest day.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh my goodness.

speaker: Christoble
words: I was hurt so bad because I kept thinking where's my enemy? That's what I want to know. What enemy? It never did come out. Beverly Tucker, my best friend, I put my arm in this coat, my hand around her waist, and she put her arm in that way, then we went walking with the hood, our heads together. It was real uncomfortable, and went home. That's how I got home.

speaker: Andrea
words: They used to do some horrible things.

speaker: Christoble
words: My mama said, where's your coat? I said, "They put it in the toilet and pooped on it." She got me a coat, but she was very disturbed by it. She said, "Did you tell anybody?" Ain't nobody-- Man, they ain't--

speaker: Andrea
words: They're not going to listen. They're not going to listen.

speaker: Richard
words: She called and raised a little hell about it with the principal.

speaker: Christoble
words: She called and she'd go out there to the school, said she didn't expect us to be treated that way, but that just didn't help none.

speaker: Richard
words: To get a quality education we had to put up at a bunch of mess.

speaker: Christoble
words: We got dogged to get quality. We got abused for quality.

speaker: Richard
words: It was rough.

speaker: Leslie
words: Do you feel like the quality actually improved? You've talked about how hard it was to sit and take a test when you dealing with somebody putting boogers on you.

speaker: Andrea
words: On your desk.

speaker: Leslie
words: On your desk and stuff like that. Did the quality improve for y'all?

speaker: Richard
words: I think for the children maybe eight years later, six years later, it started, but the first two or three years, I don't think so.

speaker: Christoble
words: I don't think it did us any good because my class in 1971 still has a class reunion and don't invite the Blacks?

speaker: Leslie
words: What?

speaker: Christoble
words: To this day?

speaker: Andrea
words: My class actually, I ran into Buddy Armour, I was in class with Buddy. He just told me this past weekend, he said, "We need to meet and have a class reunion." I do recall the last class reunion that I attended at Morganton, it was after I got back from Chicago and some of the students that betrayed me when I was in middle school and high school were there. One came up and actually hugged me. Oh, Andrea, it's so nice-- Elaine Sites. I said, "That's the one that called me a nigga." [laughter] I said, "I'm above that now." It was strange how they act like they knew you so well and now they were loving up to you and I just said, "I'm not going to stoop to their level. I'm a different person now."

speaker: Leslie
words: Have any of them ever apologized?

speaker: Andrea
words: No.

speaker: Christoble
words: No. We had our class, Loretta Putin. Remember her?

speaker: Andrea
words: I remember.

speaker: Christoble
words: She'd been organizing our class reunion they said, for years. Kathy Smith that works at Blueline, she told me. I asked her, I said, "When?" She said, Loretta was talking about having another class reunion, she said. I said, are they thinking about inviting any of us this time? She said, "You know how Loretta is." It ain't changed.

speaker: Andrea
words: This would be our 50th.

speaker: Christoble
words: We supposed to have our 50th, but we don't have a class. I'm kindly glad the school's tore down.

speaker: Leslie
words: Not good.

speaker: Christoble
words: Because now I don't have no reminder.

speaker: Leslie
words: Man.

speaker: Christoble
words: It's like it's a relief. Let me tell you this, do you know the class of 1948, I think it is constructing a wall out there in that field somewhere, but they supposedly don't have nothing for the Blacks or integration because they said they wasn't involved in that.

speaker: Leslie
words: Morganton High School Class of 1948?

speaker: Christoble
words: They said they're constructing a wall, but they don't have nothing-- They want nothing to do with the integration movement with that part. They want us to buy brick now, but we don't know where we're going to put it.

speaker: Leslie
words: Where's this wall supposed to go?

speaker: Christoble
words: Where the old school was, somewhere up there. [crosstalk] old apartment. To mark the spot [crosstalk] right here, the spot that they said that the class of that year, 1948 or whatever it is, I can't get the detail. Gary Harbison knows, but said that they don't want to get involved in the racial part. We still ain't got no part.

speaker: Andrea
words: Of course.

speaker: Richard
words: I think our mothers had a very good idea and a wise plan to try to get better education for us. Not necessarily, I don't think it happened for us, but I think down-

speaker: Andrea
words: For generations to come?

speaker: Richard
words: - the road because of what we-

speaker: Christoble
words: Even now.

speaker: Richard
words: - endured and went through, I think the kids underneath us, when they started coming up, it was a lot better.

speaker: Christoble
words: A whole lot better.

speaker: Richard
words: A lot of them got quality education but at first whenever we went, we just caught hell.

speaker: Christoble
words: Now that I think about that too, they like each other, they started growing up together. A lot of them have remained friends that belong-- They have benefited from it. Because a lot of them, White and Black have remained friends, they went to school together.

speaker: Leslie
words: You're talking about the younger kids?

speaker: Christoble
words: The younger generation.

speaker: Richard
words: Younger generation. Our mother's efforts didn't go to waste.

speaker: Leslie
words: It paid off?

speaker: Richard
words: - worked out but it was years later before the actual idea they had in mind started to--

speaker: Christoble
words: Spread it and work in this town.

speaker: Richard
words: Started to take effect.

speaker: Leslie
words: That's an excellent point. Because you hear these stories of how hard it was on you all. We tell stories about people who sat at countertops or got arrested or whatever, y'all lived with this every day for however long. This was every day in kids.

speaker: Richard
words: That's right.

speaker: Christoble
words: In your formative years.

speaker: Leslie
words: In your formative years, when your identity and self-worth is formed.

speaker: Christoble
words: Your self-esteem and everything is building, and they tell you, you nothing.

speaker: Leslie
words: Wow, wow. There was a great sacrifice that you all ended up making as young people that paved the way for people who came later. Because my experience wasn't like that. I don't know if I ever had one of my white classmates call me a nigger.

speaker: Richard
words: Are you from Morganton?

speaker: Leslie
words: I'm from Lenoir.

speaker: Christoble
words: Oh, God. It was worse over there.

speaker: Leslie
words: Yes. I remember the older kids having the police spraying them with mace and stuff like that, but it didn't trickle down to my age group. I think the kids who hit that first got hit with a brick.

speaker: Christoble
words: Yes, we did. Then too, even at sporting events and stuff, that first year, we wasn't welcome, Black people was playing. They didn't really want--

speaker: Leslie
words: They wanted your people to play.

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes. They wanted your people to play.

speaker: Christoble
words: They wanted them to win. [crosstalk]

speaker: Andrea
words: What hit me again was when I played basketball in the ninth grade, and I got to play in the 10th grade. Then that's when they came and told me and said, You can't play on the team anymore because you're too old. That was because--

speaker: Christoble
words: They done put you back all that time [crosstalk]

speaker: Andrea
words: Two years and then now you're going to take what? The sport that I'm interested in away from me. You can be the manager on the team, but I want to play basketball. That hurt again. You threw a rock at me again.

speaker: Christoble
words: The cheerleaders, we didn't have any cheerleaders. We had girls with big mouths. I tried out for cheerleader, they didn't take me. That was my first year at Morganton Junior. My second year in eighth grade, I tried, but they didn't take me. Anyway, when we got to Morganton High, we wanted some cheerleaders of color because our boys was playing. We needed some color. They wouldn't give us nobody, so we walked out of school. We went to Reverend Mack, told him about it, and he told us, he said, "Be calm. Do it organized. Go over to Slades Chapel, sit on the steps, and I'll meet you up there." He dared the boys to leave and get to drinking wine, you how boys do. He said, "I want everybody on the--" We were going to leave there and walk to the Board of Education and let them know our complaint. The day we left, those teachers, "We glad you niggas is gone. Leave." Slamming doors, telling us, "Go. Don't come back. Good riddance."

speaker: Leslie
words: Well, now tell me about what happened when y'all went over the Slades. How did that go?

speaker: Christoble
words: When we all went over there and we started singing songs, "We Shall Overcome" and all the songs called Martin Luther King was doing that time. We started singing those songs. Rev Mac came and he prayed with us, and he told us to go single fil e, the Board of Education then was out there by Teeters, where Whole Foods is. We walked out there. He let us join there in the office, but there was only him and another student to speak.The superintendents were there then, and he went in, talked to the superintendent, and told him what was going on. Everybody was running crazy, wanting to know What's going on? What's going on? He told him that we needed some cheerleaders. We were tired of the way we were been treated and we were demanding a change. They gave us what, three? Ruthie, Viola, and ...

speaker: Andrea
words: Wasn't Ruth Roseboro?.

speaker: Christoble
words: Ruth Roseboro, yes.

speaker: Andrea
words: Was a cheerleader.

speaker: Christoble
words: We ended up with three cheerleaders, and when they seen that, things started to change a little. The pressure wasn't as bad, but it still wasn't good.

speaker: Leslie
words: You had to push for everything you got. Nothing was a given.

speaker: Andrea
words: It wasn't given.

speaker: Christoble
words: To even have a locker, you had to push. You had to be verbal. You had to show strength. You had to just to be able to say, "I'm here. Recognize me."

speaker: Richard
words: I think it helped me out in the long run because after high school, I was in the military, and I stayed 30 years. There's prejudice in the military too. Not only against Blacks, but Hispanics, Asians.

speaker: Christoble
words: Anybody who ain't white.

speaker: Richard
words: Coming from Morganton taught me to how to cope with it and deal with it.

speaker: Christoble
words: It did.

speaker: Richard
words: I stayed in the military for 30 years, so I think it really helped me a whole lot.

speaker: Leslie
words: There's a whole skill set you had to develop because you were a person of color.

speaker: Richard
words: That's right.

speaker: Christoble
words: That's so true because it helped me.

speaker: Andrea
words: Me too.

speaker: Christoble
words: When I left and was gone 28 years, it helped me.

speaker: Leslie
words: Where did you go?

speaker: Christoble
words: My husband was military and like my brother, we just went everywhere, around the world and back. The greatest joy I've ever felt about being a Black American was when I was in Germany. This communist told me, he said, "You go home, you American-ish." I said, "That sounds better than you go home, nigga." [laughter]

speaker: Andrea
words: It happened to me over in France.

speaker: Christoble
words: He didn't like me because I was American.

speaker: Andrea
words: They didn't like me over in France because I was American, not a Black person and I kept saying, "Oh my God." [laughter]

speaker: Andrea
words: I'm American. [laughter]

speaker: Richard
words: They accept you a lot better over there.

speaker: Christoble
words: They do.

speaker: Richard
words: They accept you a lot better.

speaker: Christoble
words: They just talk about you--

speaker: Richard
words: You're a human being to them, you're not a person of color. They treat you like a human being. Even Morganton High, there was some that I look forward to seeing in the morning so I'd go to school but there was some that treat me real nice. If I went to an auditorium, I had two buddies that would come and sit with me. They had to take the, "Nigga lover," but they still held their heads up high and sit with me.

speaker: Leslie
words: Stepped up. What year did you graduate?

speaker: Leslie
words: 68. And you were?

speaker: Leslie
words: Okay.

speaker: Christoble
words: When he left in '68, my oldest sister already gone. That was my only link of protection.

speaker: Leslie
words: You were going by yourself at that point?

speaker: Christoble
words: I had a younger sister when I grew up.

speaker: Andrea
words: That was in my grade.

speaker: Christoble
words: That meant that I was on my own. It was kind of scary.

speaker: Leslie
words: You mentioned one time that you walked to school and sounded like you were leaning on the protection of your brother.

speaker: Christoble
words: Not leaning, I was dependent on it.

speaker: Richard
words: It was a long walk too. [laughter]

speaker: Richard
words: It's a long walk there. Yeah, long walk.

speaker: Christoble
words: Come from Bouchelle. You know where Bouchelle, Mountain Recreation? All the way across town, down through there, and going to Morganton Junior High.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh gosh, that is a long way.

speaker: Christoble
words: Rain, sleet, snow or hail, you had to go. We didn't ride no bus, we walked.

speaker: Richard
words: I tell you something else, too. Being at Morganton High, we had to walk home every day. We went by Woolworth's, it could be pouring down rain.

speaker: Leslie
words: Where was that?

speaker: Andrea
words: Where the Kimbrell's building is.

speaker: Christoble
words: Where Kimbrells is.

speaker: Richard
words: You couldn't go in no store. If it was raining, scared the cold, no. Y'all are still-- Stay outside. They would not let you in the store,

speaker: Christoble
words: The Whites would come up the sidewalks full force and we'd walk, had to get off the sidewalk, and get in the street.

speaker: Andrea
words: That's the way it was coming from Morganton Junior High trying to go home to West Concord Street.

speaker: Christoble
words: All the way.

speaker: Andrea
words: They would push us off the sidewalk coming down the sidewalk, clapping their hands. (singing) "We hate niggers. We hate niggers."

speaker: Andrea
words: After a while, we got fed up with it. Candace, Revelee, and myself was the main ones that would be walking that route after we left school and they would actually start that song again, "We hate niggas." I said, "Candace, I'll tell you what, you see that guy right there, he's mine." I said, "That girl with her, that's mine." I said, Now, the rest of them y'all can do whatever.

speaker: Christoble
words: You had to do that.

speaker: Andrea
words: We fought until they finally would depart and let us walk through.

speaker: Christoble
words: That's what they did to us going down the Bouchelle. We had to go through there like a ram rock. You had to go to through-- You'd get tired. A bunch of you'd get together and just hold up to your-- And just go through-- Who wants to live like that?

speaker: Leslie
words: Gosh.

speaker: Andrea
words: Then they would run home, tell their parents. Their parents would call the school and then our parents would come down on us.

speaker: Christoble
words: The police would be more visible. When things like that happen, just intimidate and scare us? The police walking.

speaker: Leslie
words: The police would come around when--

speaker: Christoble
words: After we done had a confrontation.

speaker: Andrea
words: Because we were the one that fought.

speaker: Christoble
words: Because we decided we got enough. They said we was aggressive, we was fighting them. They don't talk about how they would come up and we had to get inside, and you get tired. When we got tired, like y'all, we ram up together and just go run down through them like they bowling balls and knock them. Next day or so, the police-- You know what that's for.

speaker: Andrea
words: They were running up and down the street helping them out.

speaker: Richard
words: I seen the time that it'd be raining cold, and you could not go in the store. If you were one or two, but if you're in a group--

speaker: Andrea
words: You can't go in.

speaker: Christoble
words: Especially don't go into Roses or Woolworth. Whoa.

speaker: Andrea
words: What you talking about? [chuckles]

speaker: Christoble
words: If you go get something to eat, you had to go down the counter and they'd go, "We don't serve niggas here." We had to go over at Dave Rader's to the Green Fly, we called it. The little back door? And get a hamburger.

speaker: Richard
words: He wouldn't let you in, either.

speaker: Christoble
words: He wouldn't let you in either, nasty joint. But if You go through the back door you get a hamburger for a quarter. (laughter]

speaker: Leslie
words: The Green Fly? [laughter]

speaker: Richard
words: That's what we called it.

speaker: Christoble
words: It was Dave Rader's Cafe. We could go there and get a sandwich, but you'd go to the back door.

speaker: Richard
words: Yes, we called it The Green Fly.

speaker: Christoble
words: It was a little run down and it be-- The best thing about it, that little Black man in there cooking, he'd bring you a sandwich and get your $1 whatever. Then you go to the movie-

speaker: Andrea
words: You got to sit in the back.

speaker: Christoble
words: - and they'd pee in cups and throw them on you.

speaker: Leslie
words: What?

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes, we had to sit up at the balcony at the Mimosa Theater.

speaker: Christoble
words: They'd be over on the other side. They'd pee in cups and stuff and throw them over on top of you.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh, my goodness.

speaker: Andrea
words: We couldn't come into the theater, we had to go up the back door.

speaker: Christoble
words: Up the steps.

speaker: Andrea
words: Up them steps up to the back of the--

speaker: Christoble
words: You had to stand there and knock on the door. You had paid your money, but you couldn't go.

speaker: Richard
words: Somebody would come up from downstairs and ran up there and open the door for you.

speaker: Andrea
words: Open the door.

speaker: Christoble
words: Then you paid down here for your ticket, but you'd come out, go outside

speaker: Andrea
words: Go up inside the building and go ...

speaker: Christoble
words: - go up the step and go up that little side door. You might miss a part because they come get you when they get ready.

speaker: Leslie
words: Wow.

speaker: Richard
words: I don't think people in Alabama, Mississippi had anything on us. Except we didn't turn the other cheek too often. [laughter]

speaker: Richard
words: Enough was enough.

speaker: Leslie
words: Well, how did your mothers-- How did they respond to that? To the way you all were being treated?

speaker: Christoble
words: They always felt it will get better. We were the sacrificial lamb.

speaker: Richard
words: My mother always told me, don't let anyone hurt you. They try to physically hurt you, you have to defend yourself.

speaker: Christoble
words: That was it.

speaker: Andrea
words: That's what my father always told me.

speaker: Christoble
words: Yeah, "Don't start it, but if you have to finish it, you finish it. Don't let them hurt you. Don't let them do nothing Because I'm with you ." My mama used to say, "I got you. I got you." They didn't want us to bully-- Just go start-

speaker: Andrea
words: Don't start stuff, we didn't do that.

speaker: Christoble
words: - They said, "If they do something, you better take them out."

speaker: Andrea
words: That's what my daddy used to tell me.

speaker: Christoble
words: That's why I tell you, back then l'd've carried a gun to school.

speaker: Richard
words: It was rough.

speaker: Christoble
words: You felt like carrying a stick-- If you had a stick you could fold up and pull out. [laughter]

speaker: Andrea
words: pull it out. [laughter]

speaker: Leslie
words: Take some nun-chucks or something to school with you? [laughter] Wow.

speaker: Christoble
words: It was horrible.

speaker: Richard
words: I gave an interview one time over here in the library. I don't know if they still use it or not.

speaker: Andrea
words: I bet it is. I got one.

speaker: Christoble
words: A lot of people said that they heard your interview and they said they really liked it. Brenda Brewer told me said, "Richard told it just like it was."

speaker: Richard
words: To believe that people who do that actually do that.

speaker: Christoble
words: They'd do anything to you. The things that you would be shamefully to say, they didn't care.

speaker: Andrea
words: Exactly.

speaker: Christoble
words: They didn't care what they-- You didn't put nothing past them either.

speaker: Richard
words: Then if you had a big exam, you had to go home and all the stuff you're going through during the day and try to study and concentrate. It's hard. It's very difficult.

speaker: Leslie
words: No doubt.

speaker: Richard
words: Very difficult to prepare yourself for a test.

speaker: Christoble
words: I couldn't stand Put, either.

speaker: Richard
words: Me neither.

speaker: Andrea
words: You know Put?

speaker: Christoble
words: I couldn't stand him.

speaker: Andrea
words: By the time I got to my senior year, I got used to Put.

speaker: Christoble
words: I couldn't stand that white guy.

speaker: Andrea
words: Prior to that.

speaker: Leslie
words: Now, who is Put?

speaker: Andrea
words: Mr. Putnam

speaker: Richard
words: We had a Ku Klux Klansman [crosstalk][laughter]

speaker: Christoble
words: He had the hat on and the robe and everything right there in class. [laughter] This is how he walked. You've seen Mr. Tudball on Carol Burnett?

speaker: Leslie
words: Yes.

speaker: Christoble
words: He didn't have no personality, didn't have nothing, and he'd look at you and call you nigga as to look at you.

speaker: Andrea
words: You know he was never--

speaker: Leslie
words: What was he?

speaker: Andrea
words: He was an instructor.

speaker: Christoble
words: He a North Carolina teacher. You had to pass his class to graduate.

speaker: Andrea
words: He always called me High Pockets, he never called me by my name.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh, my goodness.

speaker: Andrea
words: He called me High Pockets because I was on the basketball team at the time. He will always say, "Well, High Pockets, how many points are you going to hit tonight?" High Pockets this, you know, but never addressed me by my name.

speaker: Christoble
words: He didn't address any of us with any kind of curtesy,

speaker: Leslie
words: So rude.

speaker: Christoble
words: He didn't address you, and he'd say, "You. Hey you." I'd just look at him and say to myself, "I hate you."

speaker: Leslie
words: You said a lot of kids just dropped out. About how many would you think just couldn't take it and dropped out?

speaker: Andrea
words: I know my sister Anna, she dropped out of school. By the time she got to the high school, she dropped out.

speaker: Leslie
words: Now, where would Annabella [her sister, Anna] have been?

speaker: Andrea
words: Would have been in Morganton High School when she dropped out. [crosstalk]

speaker: Leslie
words: She would have finished in--

speaker: Andrea
words: She would have been in 1970.

speaker: Christoble
words: A lot of the students that dropped out were students that came from-We were all poor, but came from-- They was poorer than us. Because they were made fun of so bad-- One thing about our parents, they worked hard and tried to clothe us and do the best, but you had some that came from a real, real lower poverty level than where we were. They couldn't take it. They went to the Black school, the teachers, everybody knew they situation, everybody tried to help. They would give clothes. I remember we had a student, they father left them, and they was bringing clothes-- My mom told me, "Take these clothes down in to school." I took them to Miss Hamilton's room, they was giving clothes and stuff-- You knew about things and nobody was a failure. When they integrated the schools, they didn't have any help. Then they got sneered.

speaker: Andrea
words: See on West Concord Street, most of the families were large families. Mildred had seven girls, and my family, there was seven of us. I was the middle of seven.

speaker: Christoble
words: I didn't know they were seven of y'all.

speaker: Andrea
words: There was Roy Irvin, Annabel, then me, then Jeannie, Gary Dean, and-

speaker: Christoble
words: I never know because I spent so many nights out there, it seemed like there was so much room. [laughter]

speaker: Andrea
words: Rose Johnson, she had about six or seven.

speaker: Christoble
words: That was four of us.

speaker: Andrea
words: There was a lot of-- West Concord was a big family. Bobby Forney, they had a big family. [crosstalk] The whole street was-

speaker: Christoble
words: The whole street was big ....

speaker: Andrea
words: - big families but we were one united family.

speaker: Christoble
words: See, we would go over there because like Ruth and them was our cousin...We'd go spend the night with each other and you go out there in the street and you just play ball with kids everywhere, but excuse me, when we started going to school.

speaker: Leslie
words: That dynamic just changed.

speaker: Christoble
words: No, we remained the same because we had to replenish our strengths. On weekends, all of us would get together and have a game plan going on. We got to get them. The Blacks, the seven mothers-- The kids I think were always close. Then the seven mothers joined together for us to have a better education. When school was out, we clung to each other because we were going through the same thing. We didn't have no place in the Black world and the White world, but we had each other.

speaker: Leslie
words: Now, help me get it right about that first year. That first year, y'all went for a while.

speaker: Christoble
words: The whole year.

speaker: Leslie
words: Did you go the whole year?

speaker: Andrea
words: Yes. [crosstalk] Integration went the whole year.

speaker: Leslie
words: lntergration was the following year. Okay.

speaker: Christoble
words: The seven mothers sent their kids in '64. lntergration came fu ll-fledged I think '65.

speaker: Richard
words: We was at Morganton High for the whole year with just me being the only in every class. There was only five of us in Morganton High. It was hell for the first year. The next year, everybody came so, it kindly took a lot of pressure off of you, but the first year was hell.

speaker: Christoble
words: Because the girls like Daisy and all of them that bullied us little people, they became my friends. We was all bullying them. [laughter]

speaker: Andrea
words: Because my daddy told me, he said, "If you come home one more time telling me about what Daisy had done to you."

speaker: Leslie
words: Now Daisy's Black?

speaker: Christoble
words: Yes. She was black, but she was a big girl.

speaker: Richard
words: Yeah, she was a big girl.

speaker: Andrea
words: He said, "I'm going to whip you."

speaker: Richard
words: Daisy used to play football.

speaker: Andrea
words: I didn't want no whipping from my daddy, so I had to whoop Daisy.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh my.

speaker: Andrea
words: I had to whoop her, really whoop her! [laughter].

speaker: Christoble
words: Daisy was bullying us, we were good to her. Used to kill me [laughter] And she was kin to us. And she ... "Give me your money." After Daisy got to Morganton High, Daisy was helping us bully them. [laughter]

speaker: Leslie
words: She had to change.

speaker: Andrea
words: Change her stripe.

speaker: Christoble
words: Her bullying style.

speaker: Richard
words: You had the help the next young. The name calling, like by myself at Morganton High, I could be walking down the hall, and somebody just holler out but when they came over next year, you do that and somebody standing close to you, you may get a hit upside the head. The name-calling died down. They might tell you one-on-one if you are in a room or outside or something, but as a group inside you paid the price.

speaker: Leslie
words: Because you weren't by yourself. You weren't vulnerable at that point.

speaker: Christoble
words: You know that jewelry store, Gregory Jewelry, their son was Steven Gregory. That was one of the racists.

speaker: Richard
words: That's my classmate.

speaker: Christoble
words: He was a racist and he's crippled.

speaker: Leslie
words: Oh, my goodness.

speaker: Christoble
words: Crippled bad. He hated Blacks, I think. He was mean in school. He'd kick at you as to speak to you .

speaker: Richard
words: There was several of them like that.

speaker: Andrea
words: That Richard Elmore is the one that stepped on my foot and pushed me into the locker. I went to the teacher, I followed them to his classroom, and I went to the teacher and I said, "One of your students just pushed me into the locker. Didn't say excuse me, stepped on my toes." I said, "What you going to do about it?" She's looked at me like I was crazy. Politely, I walked up to him at his desk, Deborah O'Neil and Alice Kay can confess to this, and I slapped a pee out of him. Excuse my French. Then I went back up to the middle of the class and to the teacher's desk and I said, "Excuse me for disturbing your class," and walked out. They said--

speaker: Christoble
words: That's one thing--

speaker: Leslie
words: What'd they do to you?

speaker: Andrea
words: They didn't do anything. They said, "Well, you're going to have to go to the principal office." I said, "well Abernathy don't want to see me." [laughs] Alice said, "If Mr. Abernathy say something, said Jamie Pearson, and all of them going to come up in here."

speaker: Christoble
words: We start sticking together when they stopped getting us together.

speaker: Richard
words: Even though the following year we all came over. I was already there, but everybody else came over, I think a lot of black kids still didn't get the education, the assistance that they needed.

speaker: Andrea
words: They didn't.

speaker: Richard
words: The dropout rate for the first three or four years was probably pretty high.

speaker: Christoble
words: It was.
